name: Kevin Barry
description: Kevin Barry gained a silver medal in the light-heavyweight division at the Olympic Games in Los Angeles in 1984 after his semi-final opponent, future heavyweight champion Evander Holyfield, was disqualified. Referee Gligorije Novičić of Yugoslavia disqualified Holyfield for continuing to fight after he had called break. Barry had been knocked down and because of that, he was not allowed to contest the final against Ante Josipović of Yugoslavia. Barry took up coaching in 1990 and had a long association with an Olympic bronze medallist from Barcelona, David Tua, including an unsuccessful world heavyweight challenge against Lennox Lewis of Great Britain. The two parted in 2003. Barry married Tania Moss, a member of the New Zealand gymnastics team in Los Angeles in 1984.
special_notes: Husband of Tania Moss Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–0–1 1982 Brisbane BOX bronze: light-heavyweight -81 kg)

name: Sarina Hülsenbeck
description: Sarina Hülsenbeck qualified for the 1980 Moskva Olympics and was a member of the 4x100 metres freestyle relay squad. She gained selection after finishing fourth in the 100 metres free at both the 1979 and 1980 East German nationals. Hülsenbeck then won the relay gold medal at the Olympics, and swam in the 4x100 medley relay heats but not in the final. As gold medals were not awarded for all members of a relay squad until 1984, she was not awarded the gold at Moskva because she did not swim in the final. Hülsenbeck later married Frank Fischer, brother of legendary flatwater canoeist Birgit Fischer-Schmidt, and raised her children Fanny and non-Olympian Falco Fischer, who were also flatwater canoeists. Hülsenbeck-Fischer also became the mother-in-law of Ronald Rauhe after his marriage to Fanny. Hülsenbeck was a schoolteacher by profession.

description: Gymnast Emil Rotong finished 59th at the 1900 Paris Olympics in the individual all-around. He was born in Alsace, which was German between 1870 and 1918. No more results from Rotong could be identified.

name: Stefan Wenz
description: Stefan Wenz was a West German freestyle swimmer who specialized in the long-distance events at the Olympic Games. In 1976 at Montréal he competed in the 400 and 1,500 metre events, but was eliminated in the heats of both. The following year he won his only West German national title, the 1,500 metres freestyle.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Aquatics Championships (1–0–0 1974 Wien SWM gold: 4×200 m freestyle relay (swam in heats only))

name: Kerstin Köppen
description: German rower Kerstin Köppen partnered Katrin Boron at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics in the double sculls, and won the gold medal. Therefore, the pair were awarded the Silver Bay Leaf, Germany’s highest sports award. Four years later they both rowed with the quadruple sculls, and again won the gold medal. At World Championships, Köppen won gold medals in the quadruple sculls with the former GDR in 1990, and then with re-unified Germany in 1990, 1994-95, and 1997. With Boron, she also added a silver medal in the double sculls in 1993. In 1998, Köppen, was awarded the Thomas-Keller-Medal, the highest sports award for rowers worldwide. Köppen later became a graduated sports teacher and married rowing coach Ralf Holtmeyer.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–0–1 1989 Duisburg ROW bronze: quadruple sculls)

name: Ron Skarin
description: Ron Skarin competed on the roads for the United States at the 1972 Olympics, riding the team time trial, and then was a track racer in 1976, riding in the team pursuit. Skarin was quite versatile, winning 10 US titles from 1971-81, with six in the team pursuit, the 1975 individual pursuit, the 1976 10-mile scratch race, the 1978 points race, and the 1981 Madison. He was champion on the roads at the 1973-74 Tour of Somerville, at the time the premier single-day race in the United States. Skarin won a gold medal in team pursuit at the 1975 Pan American Games. Skarin also competed in Human Powered Vehicle (HPV) racing. Between 1973-80 he broke several records for HPV speed records, including the men’s hour record, which he set in May 1979 at Ontario Motor Speedway in California, covering 51.310 km. In 1980 he also helped set the tandem hour record of 74.497 km. Skarin stayed in cycling as an administrator. He was Director of the US Cycling Federation from 1979-80, and was an assistant coach of the US cycling team at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics. Skarin was also a director at the Encino Velodrome from 1981-86 and coached introductory track cycling classes at the velodrome.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 1975 Ciudad de México CYC gold: 4000 m pursuit team)

name: Davie Holt
description: Davie Holt joined Queen’s Park from Lugar Boswell Thistle Juniors in 1954 and spent six seasons in the Scottish League with the amateur club. During his time with them he was selected for Great Britain at the 1960 Olympics and he played at left-back in all three matches. After the Olympics he became a full-time professional with Heart of Midlothian and made 231 League appearances for the Edinburgh club before moving to Partick Thistle in 1970 for one season before retiring after more than 300 League games. Between 1963 and 1964 he won four full Scottish international caps, playing alongside some of Scotland’s great players; Jim Baxter, Ian St John, Denis Law, Dave Mackay, Davie Wilson and Frank McLintock.

name: Mary Anne Marchino
description: Mary Anne Marchino was the daughter of Elmer Marchino, who was a big supporter and administrator of swimming both in Indianapolis and at the national level. Mary Anne swam for the Indianapolis Athletic Club and Indiana University, but later represented Riviera Country Club. She placed second seven times in AAU backstroke events, unable to defeat the era’s world best backstroker, Carin Cone. A graduate of Purdue University, Marchino later taught kindergarten, owned a craft business, and raised a family of five children with her husband, Gene Witchger.

name: Mihajlo Jancović
description: Mihajlo Janković was one of the most important representatives of post-war Yugoslav architecture and made a great contribution to the reconstruction of Beograd (Belgrade). In 1936 he graduated from the Faculty of Technology in Beograd with a degree in architecture. After working in the military construction offices, Janković founded his own studio “Stadion”, which he managed until his death in 1976. His projects for sports stadiums, such as Stadium JNA and Stadium “Tašmajdan,” deserve special mention. His major projects for the state and the Communist Party, including the Palace of the Federation and the Palace of the Central Committee of the SKJ, earned him the unofficial title of the “Palace Architect” of the Tito regime, although Janković never became a member of the party. His style was modern and internationally recognized. Janković’s father was also an architect. The Partizan Stadium is a football and athletics stadium in Beograd, originally named JNA Stadium (Stadium of the Yugoslav People’s Army). Mihajlo Janković and Kosta Popović were still little known as architects, and it came as a surprise when they were awarded the contract. They followed the principles of functionalism. Construction of the stadium began in 1948, and it was officially opened in the following year with an international football match between Yugoslavia and France. It was not completed, however, until 1951. The stadium originally had a capacity of about 55,000 spectators. After renovation, it was reduced to about 30,000 seats due to new security regulations. The pitch measures 105 x 70 meters and the stands have 30 rows of seats with 30 entrances for spectators.

name: Trish Tipper
description: Trish Tipper was a British speed skater who competed at the 1968 Grenoble Winter Olympics. During her career she set 19 British records over every distance from 500 to 3,000 metres. She raced internationally only in the winter of 1967/68, skating at Inzell and Cortina, in addition to her Olympic appearance. Tipper became a dancer and dance instructor. She married Phil Liggett, best known as a television broadcaster of cycling events, notably the Tour de France. Both Phil and Trish Liggett were avid bird-watchers and wildlife photographers, who also spent a lot of time in Africa.

name: Damon Keeve
description: Damon Keeve was a judoka who competed at the 1992 and 1996 Olympics. He also won two medals in judo at the Pan American Games, winning silver in 1987 in the open class, and bronze as a heavyweight in 1995. He was seven-time US Champion. Keeve attended San José State where he played football. He became a San Francisco police officer and SWAT Team member. Keev also coached football in the San Francisco area, initially as an assistant at Galileo, Washington, and then Lincoln High Schools. At Washington High the teams he coached won city championships in 1997, 1999, 2000, and 2003, and had a 33-game winning streak. He later became an assistant and then head coach at Terra Linda High School.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–1–1 1987 Indianapolis JUD silver: open class; 1995 Mar del Plata JUD bronze: heavyweight +95 kg)

name: Ritsudo Kobayashi
description: Japanese painter Ritsudo Kobayashi was born in Tokyo and studied under Shoko Kawasaki. He became a very competent painter with an eye for a very delicate image, particularly painting birds and flowers. Kobayashi was a member of Japanese Artists’ Association (Nihonga-kai) for some time and was awarded several prizes for his work at various official exhibitions (e.g. Bunten). Besides hanging scrolls, he left a lot of miniature works. The original Japanese title of his 1936 entry, Yukigassen, actually means “snowball fight”. Part of this painting appears in the background of a photo of the Japanese hall at the art exhibition in Berlin.

name: Henri Chammartin
description: A son of farmers, Henri Chammartin graduated from the Field-Artillery Recruit School in Thun. From 1949 until his retirement Chammartin was employed by the Swiss Federal Military Horse Training Center in Bern. Exclusively a dressage rider, Chammartin competed at five consecutive Olympics starting in 1952 and won individual gold in 1964, team silvers in 1952 and 1964 and team bronzes in 1956 and 1968. He also won a team dressage silver at the 1966 World Championships. At the European Championships in dressage, he won individual gold in 1963 and 1965, team silver in 1965, individual bronze in 1963, while riding two different horses, and team bronze in 1967.

special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (0–0–1 1994 Hiroshima BDM bronze: team)

name: Kálmán Marvalits
description: Kálmán Marvalits started his sports career in 1919 in his hometown, with Nagykanizsa Torna Egylet (NTE). In 1922 he moved to MTK before returning to NTE in 1923-24, and from 1925-30 he was a member of the BTC. He started as a javelin thrower, but from 1921 competed only in discus and shot. He competed in both the 1924 Paris and 1928 Amsterdam Olympics. Between 1926-30 Marvalits won five consecutive Hungarian discus titles, and in 1927 he won the English AAA title in the same event, beating fellow Hungarian Kálmán Egri into second place. After finishing his active career, Marvalits worked as a coach.
special_notes: Uncle of Györgyi Marvalics-Székely

name: Thomas Rzeznizok
description: West German luger Thomas Rzeznizok came in 12th at the 1984 Sarajevo Winter Olympics in the men’s singles event. In 1981 and 1984 he won West German national titles. At the World Championships he placed 12th in 1977, 14th in 1981, 12th in 1983, and 13th in 1985. At the European Championships Rzeznizok finished 9th in 1978, 15th in 1980, and 10th in 1984.

name: Victor Costello
description: Victor Costello won his first national shot put title at the age of just sixteen and won five Irish titles between 1987 and 1991. He retired from athletics following the Barcelona Games and turned his attention to rugby. Costello, who played provincial rugby for Connacht and Leinster, made his debut for Ireland against the USA in 1996 and went on to play 39 times for Ireland as a back row forward including at the 2003 Rugby World Cup. Costello scored four tries for his country. He matched the achievements of his father, Pat Costello, who was also both national shot put champion and an Irish international rugby player. Personal Best: SP – 19.93 (1992).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Played in the Rugby World Cup (Played 39 times for Ireland including the 2003 Rugby World Cup)

name: Donatella Ferracuti
special_notes: Sister of Antonio Ferracuti Sister of Carmen Ferracuti Sister of Piero Ferracuti

name: Émile-Florent Lecomte
description: Émile-Florent Lecomte was a Belgian impressionistic painter. He studied at the Academy of Fine Arts in Brussels, and took some courses in Genk. He painted mainly landscapes, gardens and parks, in a powerful, spontaneous style, in a color palette with attention to lighting effects. Lecomte also painted interiors, still lifes, figures and flowers, sometimes in a realistic style. He was a longtime director of the art magazine La Nervie.

name: Albert Laisant
description: Frenchman Albert Laisant was the son of Charles Ange Laisant (1841-1920), a well-known mathematician and politician. Albert was an anarchist, journalist, poet, freemason and libertarian educator. He was introduced to anarchist ideas by Sébastien Fauré, and Albert turned the whole family onto anarchism, including his father, and his two sons, Maurice and Charles. He also focused on freemasonry since 1916. Together with his sister, he was one of the founders of the Concordia Human Rights Lodge in Paris. He accepted the position as director of the Masonic orphanage under the condition that he was only in charge of educational matters, and could implement his modern approach. When charges were brought against him regarding financial problems, he quit his job.

name: André le Goupil
description: André le Goupil was a French equestrian. Le Goupil’s father had a large farm in Moon-sur-Elle, Normandy, with almost 100 horses. Le Goupil took up horse riding in 1961 and became the French champion. This resulted in him being selected as a substitute rider for the 1964 Tokyo Olympics, but he would ultimately not compete in Japan. His selection was unusual as he was a civilian, with all but one of France’s previous Olympic equestrians coming from a military background. Le Goupil would only have to wait four years to make his Olympic début when he rode at the 1968 Mexico City Games. He finished in 12th place in the individual competition, and just missed out on a medal in the team competition with France finishing in fourth place. After finishing his career, Le Goupil set up an equestrian centre near to Cherbourg, and founded the international competition le Grand Complet. One of his sons, Pierre, was selected as the course designer for the equestrian events for the 2024 Paris Olympics.

name: Vladimir Grozdanović
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Shooting Championships (0–1–0 1958 Moskva silver: 300 m standard rifle 3 positions team)

name: Anacleto Jiménez

name: Theodor Dahlberg
description: Theodor Dahlberg had the following finishes at major championships – 1909 Unofficial European Championship: Unlimited Greco-Roman (5th).

name: Mathias Zahradka
description: Weightlifter Mathias Zahradka took part in the 1936 Berlin Olympics. He finished 12th in the featherweight division. Domestically, he represented Ursus Wien (Vienna).

name: Boris Schildt
description: Boris Schildt played singles and doubles at the 1924 Paris Olympics. He lost in the first round of the singles, and he and Runar Granholm made the eighth-finals of men’s doubles. Schildt played at the 1921 World Covered Court Championships, losing in the first round.

name: Muhammad Ali
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Youth Olympic Games (0–0–1 2014 Nanjing BOX bronze: flyweight -52 kg)

name: Walter Keller
description: Walter Keller began competing in junior athletics competitions in Zürich by 1944, and later joined TV Neumünster, where spent his senior athletics career. He specialized in the 400 metres event, gaining notice by posting a time of 50.7 at an athletics meet in 1947. Selected to represent his country at the 1948 Olympics in London, Keller ran in the 400 metres and 4 × 400 metres relay events (alongside fellow Zürich athletes Oskar Hardmeier, Max Trepp and Karl Volkmer), but did not advance past the heats in either. He continued competing in local and national competitions until 1951. Personal Best: 400 – 49.5 (1948).

name: Feodosiy Golubev
description: Personal Best: 200 - 21.7 (1952).

name: Tommy Brennan
description: Tommy Brennan competed in both jumping and eventing, representing Ireland at the 1964 Olympics as an eventer, where he just missed a medal aboard Kilkenny. In 1966 he and Kilkenny won a gold medal with the Irish team at the FEI World Eventing Championships at Burghley, England. Kilkenny was later sold to Jimmy Wofford, who rode him to a team gold at the 1967 Pan American Games and team silvers at both the 1968 and 1972 Olympic Games. Brennan was brought up on the family farm in Dunnamaggin where he developed his love of horses, often hunting with the County Kilkenny Foxhounds on Saturday. He trained in animal husbandry, and then moved to Skiddoo Stud in Dublin to further his equestrian and agricultural education. He later took a key role at Skiddoo eventually running the operation. During his career Brennan had 67 international jumping wins and won nine Irish Championships. He later helped design cross-country courses for eventing, notably for the 1991 and 2003 European Championships held at Punchestown in Ireland. He served as chef d’equipe frequently for Irish junior teams, and with the senior team at the 12007 FEI Nations Cup in Linz, Austria.

name: Ed Kirby
description: In 1923, Ed Kirby won the IC4A mile for Cornell in a career best of 4:17.9 and only Joie Ray among U.S. milers ran faster that year. The following year Kirby and Ray met in the 3,000 m at the Final Trials; although Ray won comfortably Kirby proved to be the better man at the Olympics and, finishing in sixth place, he led the U.S. team home in the team race. Kirby took his degree at Cornell in civil engineering and worked for several engineering companies before his retirement in 1958. Personal Best: 3000 – 8:46e (1924).

name: Thérèse Elsen
description: Thérèse Elsen was a female painter with a preference for bird motifs. Her pictures can be found in the art collection of the Royal Zoological Society.

name: Murray Riley
description: Murray Riley partnered Merv Wood to a bronze medal in the 1956 double sculls, after the pair had won gold medals in the doubles at the 1950 and 1954 Commonwealth Games. At the time the two were both police officers, but their careers would take decidedly different courses. Wood eventually became New South Wales (NSW) Police Commissioner in 1976, but stepped down in 1979, partly because of his association with Riley who had by then turned to a life of crime. Riley joined the NSW police force in 1943, when only 17-years-old, and he eventually rose to detective-sergeant, 3rd class. Major drug investigations in the 1960s found that Riley was associated with managers of several illegal gambling casinos in Sydney and Wollongong and it led to his involvement in drugs. In 1966 he was jailed for a year in New Zealand on charges of attempting to bribe a police inspector, after he was found to be involved in drug importation and cashing stolen American Express checks. After his release he linked up with well-known Australian crime figure Wally Dean and the two became supervisors for the Sydney League Clubs, and began scamming the clubs, extorting their services at very high fees in return for protection. Riley disappeared for a few years but emerged in September 1974, helping Dean in an unsuccessful attempt to get elected to the South Sydney City Council. Riley was also involved in the Nugan Hand Bank Scandal, which was a complex arrangement fronted by the United States CIA, and former US Green Beret Michael Hand, as a front to help catch drug dealers and exporters. It was found that in April 1976, Nugan Hand made cash transfers to Riley in Hong Kong, totaling about $1.2 million. Riley used the cash to take delivery of heroin shipments. The Australian Joint Task Force on Drugs, concluded, “Throughout 1976 Hand was knowingly involved in drug activity with the ‘Riley’ group in that he permitted and even encouraged the use of Nugan Hand facilities for the movement of drug money.” Riley was finally caught in June 1978, when he was arrested after 4.3 tons of cannabis was found onboard the yacht Anoa at Polkington Reef, east of Papua New Guinea. Riley pleaded guilty and was sentenced by Judge Kenneth Torrington to 5-10 years in jail. The sentence was extended 7 years when he was found to have defrauded American Express of $274,000. Riley was released in May 1984, having served only 6 of 17 years. He soon became involved with drugs again, attempting to smuggle over 50 kg of heroin from Papua New Guinea to distribute in Australia. In October 1984, Riley came into the employ of Lennie McPherson, noted drug dealer, looking after collections from various gambling clubs and bookmakers, and providing protection for them. By the early 1990s Riley had changed his name to Murray Lee Stewart by deed poll. In October 1990 Riley/Stewart and Jonathan Nicholas Gould were arrested in Great Britain for conspiring to defraud British Aerospace PLC of £40,000,000 via computer fraud. They were convicted in July 1991 and sentenced to five years in prison. Riley had many friends and he was sent to an open prison farm at Spring Hill Prison in Aylesbury, which he simply walked out of in December 1991. He remained at large for eight weeks, traveling in Northern Ireland, Spain and Belgium before being recaptured in January 1992. He was moved to a minimum security prison in Kent, and escaped from there, with IRA help, in January 1993, settling in Hong Kong, where he lived incognito, before returning to Queensland, Australia in early 1994. In January 2008, historian Dr. John Jiggens of the Queensland University of Technology, deepened the crime connection of Riley with the publication of his book The Sydney Connection: Nugan Hand, Murray Riley, and the Murder of Donald Mackay. Mackay was a furniture store owner in the NSW town of Griffith, who in 1975, tipped off police about a large marijuana plantation at Coleambally, south of Griffith. Mackay was murdered outside the Hotel Griffith on 15 July 1977, as his bloodstained car and spent .22 cartridges were found in the hotel carpark the next day, although his body was never recovered. Jiggens notes in the book that Nugan and Riley were key figures in an international drug-smuggling group supplying the United States market in the 1970s.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (2–0–0 1950 Auckland ROW gold: double sculls; 1954 Vancouver ROW gold: double sculls) Listed in Olympians Who Were Sent to Prison (In 1966 he was jailed for a year in New Zealand on charges of attempting to bribe a police inspector. In 1978 he was arrested after 4.3 tons of cannabis was found onboard a yacht. Riley pleaded guilty and was sentenced by Judge Kenneth Torrington to 5-10 years in jail.)

name: Patterson Johnson
description: Personal Best: TJ – 16.94 (1988).

name: Cecil Pim
description: A member of the Great Britain II bobsleigh team at the 1924 Chamonix Olympics, George Pim was, like team-mates Gray Horton, Gerard Fairlie and Archie Crabbe, a member of the Scots Guards. Having finished fifth in 1924, Pim steered the Great Britain I team four years later to 10th place as he became the first British bobsleigher to compete in two Olympics. Three weeks before the St. Moritz Games, the five-man bob that Pim was steering was involved in a bad crash at the French resort, while competing in the Martineau Cup. Two other members involved in the accident, Frederick Browning and Thomas Warner went on to compete with Pim at the Olympics. Pim was owner of the bob, named “Tishy”, and in the 1927 season they won eight races on the Cresta Run.

name: Joseph Agyemang-Gyau
special_notes: Listed in Olympian Members of the Nobility (Nana Kwasi Gyau Gyan II, Atipimhene of Berekum)

name: Marcus Nash
description: Born in England, Marcus Nash’s family moved to the United States when he was 5-years-old, and settled in Maine when he was 7. He became an American citizen in 1989, and competed for the United States at the 1994 and 1998 Winter Olympics in cross-country skiing. Nash was a nine-time US Champion at various distances, and won a gold medal at the 2000 Goodwill Winter Games at Lake Placid. Nash married Kateřina Hanušová, a Czech athlete who competed at five Olympics, twice in cross-country skiing (1998, 2002) and three times in mountain biking (1996, 2012, 2016). She competed as Kateřina Hanušová from 1996-2002, and as Kateřina Nash in 2012-16. They met while training in Squaw Valley and the Sierra Nevadas, while Hanušová was on a ski scholarship at the University of Colorado, although she later transferred to Nevada-Reno to be with Nash.
special_notes: Husband of Kateřina Hanušová-Nash

name: Mikhail Voronin
description: Mikhail Voronin was the top Soviet gymnast at the end of the 1960s. The best tournament for Voronin was the 1968 Olympics, where he medaled in every event, except floor exercise, winning two gold medals (horizontal bar and vault), four silvers (individual all-around, parallel bars, rings and team event) and a pommelled horse bronze. At the 1972 Olympics, Voronin won two more silvers (rings, team event), bringing his total count of Olympic medals to nine. At the World Championships, Voronin won eight medals, including two World titles, both in 1966, in individual all-around and rings. He also won four silvers (1966/1970 team, 1966 pommelled horse and parallel bars) and two bronzes (1970 parallel bars and 1970 rings). Voronin also won eight European titles (1967/1969 individual all-around and parallel bars, 1967/1969/1971 rings and 1967 pommelled horse) and 15 medals in total at the European Championships. Domestically, Voronin was a 16-time Soviet champion (1967-68/70-71 individual all-around, 1966-67/69-72 rings, 1967/69 parallel bars, 1967/70 in pommelled horse, 1966 floor exercise, 1971 horizontal bar). Voronin finished his sporting career after the 1972 Olympics and from 1973-94 was the head coach of Dynamo Moskva gymnastics team. From 1978-88, Voronin also worked as the president of Russian SFSR Gymnastics federation. From 1994 until his death in 2004, Voronin was the president of the Dynamo Moskva gymnastics club. His first wife Zinaida Voronina was also a gymnast and 1968 Olympic champion and their son Dmitry also became an international level gymnast. Zinaida and Mikhail Voronin divorced in 1980. He died aged 59 from cancer.
special_notes: Husband (divorced) of Zinaida Voronina

name: Vladimir Pleshakov
special_notes: Twin brother of Sergey Pleshakov

name: Dirk de Ridder
special_notes: Listed in Olympic Sailors who have competed in the Volvo Ocean Race/Whitbread Race Around the World (Work in progress) (1997/98 (Merit Cup), 2001/02 (Illbruck Challenge), 2005/06 (Pirates of the Caribbean))

name: Andrea Tagwerker
description: In addition to her Olympic bronze medal at Lillehammer in 1994, Andrea Tagwerker won three World Championship gold medals in the team event – 1996, 1997, and 1999. In singles she won two medals at the European Championships with silver in 1998 and a bronze in 1996. Tagwerker was overall World Cup champion for the 1996-97 season, before that competition began to be dominated by German sliders. She was also Austrian Champion in 1994 and 2002. In 1994 Tagwerker was awarded a Gold Medal for Meritorious Service to the Austrian Republic, and in 1998 she was awarded the Silver Medal.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Luge Championships (0–3–3 1992 Winterberg silver: mixed team; 1994 Königssee bronze: mixed team; 1996 Sigulda silver: mixed team, bronze: singles; 1998 Oberhof silver: singles, bronze: mixed team) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Luge Championships (3–1–1 1991 Winterberg silver: mixed team; 1996 Altenberg gold: mixed team; 1997 Igls gold: mixed team; 1999 Königsee gold: mixed team; 2000 St. Moritz bronze: mixed team)

name: Hipólito Pozo
description: In addition to his Olympic appearance, Hipólito Pozo won the 1966 Tour of Ecuador. His brother, Jaime Eduardo, did not compete at the Olympics, but was also a talented cyclist who won the Tour of Ecuador three times: 1967 and 1971-72.
special_notes: Brother of Arnulfo Pozo

special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Swimming Championships (25 m) (0–1–1 2015 Netanya silver: 4×50 m freestyle mixed relay, bronze: 4×50 m freestyle relay)

name: Anja Lappalainen
description: Anja Lappalainen was a Finnish swimmer who represented Kotkan Uimaseura. At the 1936 Berlin Olympics Lappalainen competed in the 200 metres breaststroke. She finished in fourth place in her heat and did not progress to the semi-finals.

name: Wilfredo Peláez
description: Wilfredo Peláez was a member of the first Uruguay squad to win an Olympic basketball medal at Helsinki in 1952. They won another bronze four years later but, going into the 2020 Games, they are the only two medals Uruguay has won. However, victory was bitter-sweet for Peláez. He played in four matches at the 1952 Games, scoring two points, in the 70-56 win over Hungary, in a group match. However, his fourth appearance, against France, was to be his last in the Olympics . The match, played on 28 July 1952, was regarded as one of the most violent in basketball history. Uruguay were down to just three men for the final minute. The scores were level when the American referee Vincent Farrell called a foul against the South Americans. Their players were incensed and a violent fight broke out, and Farrell was seriously injured, and carried off the court unconscious. The police were called, and it was established that two of the biggest perpetrators of the violence were Peláez and Carlos Roselló. The two men were banned for the remainder of the tournament, and all future Olympics.

name: Luis, Conde de Figueroa
description: José de Figueroa and his brothers Álvaro and Luis were the sons of Álvaro Figueroa, the first Count of Romanones, a liberal politician and Spanish Prime Minister on three occasions between 1912 and 1919. Álvaro, who was considered the best player in Spain, and José competed in the 1920 Olympics whilst Luis and Álvaro took part in 1924. Luis played in just one mach, the 10-3 defeat by Great Britain in Paris, but with his brother alongside him it was the one and only time that any two of the siblings played together at the Olympics. Sadly, they could not emulate Spain’s silver medal winning performance at Antwerpen four years earlier as they could only finish fourth in the five-team round-robin tournament.
special_notes: Brother of José, Conde de Figueroa Brother of Álvaro, Conde de Figueroa Nephew of Gonzalo, Conde de Villamejor Listed in Olympian Members of the Nobility (Conde (Count) de la Dehesa de Velayos)

name: Harry Voigt
description: Harry Voigt, a 400 metre runner, was the brother-in-law of Erwin Blask, who married his sister Dora. She was German Champion in the 200 in 1942. Harry Voigt took a bronze medal with the 4x400 relay at the 1936 Berlin Olympic Games and won the 1934 European Championships with the relay. In 1933, he was German Champion in the open 400, and second in 1936. In 1932, he set two European records with 48.6 and 48.2. By profession Voigt was a medical counselor. Personal Best: 400 – 48.0 (1933).
special_notes: Brother-in-law of Erwin Blask Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Athletics Championships (1–0–0 1934 Torino gold: 4×400 m relay)

special_notes: Cousin of Peter Fill Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Alpine Ski Championships (0–1–1 2003 St. Moritz silver: giant slalom; 2007 Åre bronze: giant slalom)

name: Tomasz Mendelski
description: Tomasz Mendelski had the following podium finishes at the Flatwater World Championships: 2nd 2005 K1 200 m, 2nd 2006 K4 1000 m (with Paweł Baumann, Marek Twardowski, and Adam Wysocki), 2nd 2007 K4 1000 m (with Marek Twardowski, Paweł Baumann, and Adam Wysocki), 3rd 2006 K4 500 m (with Paweł Baumann, Adam Wysocki, and the non-Olympian Przemysław Gawrych).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Canoe Sprint European Championships (0–0–5 2004 Poznań bronze: K1 200 m and K4 1000 m; 2005 Poznań bronze: K4 1000 m; 2007 Pontevedra bronze: K2 500 m and K4 1000 m) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Canoe Sprint World Championships (0–3–1 2005 Zagreb silver: K1 200 m; 2006 Szeged silver: K4 1000 m, bronze: K4 500 m; 2007 Duisburg silver: K4 1000 m)

name: Ildikó Rejtő-Ujlaky-Sági
description: Ildikő Ságiné-Ujlakiné-Rejtő has the unusual distinction of winning Olympic medals under three different names – as Miss Rejtő in 1960, as Mrs. Ujlakiné-Rejtő in 1964 and 1968, and as Mrs. Ságiné-Ujlakiné-Rejtő in 1972 and 1976. She shares this with German speed skater Andrea Ehrig-Schöne-Mitscherlich. Ildikő won seven Olympic medals, including gold in the individual and team foil in 1964. At the World Championships, she won five titles – individual foil in 1963, and team foil in 1959, 1962, 1967, and 1973, and 15 medals in all, adding seven silvers and three bronzes. Her first international titles came in winning the World Junior title in 1956 and 1957. She continued competing as a senior, winning the World Veterans Championship in 1999. Ildikő was named Hungarian Sportsperson of the Year in 1963 and 1964. She was later inducted into the International Jewish Sports Hall of Fame. She accomplished all this despite being almost completely deaf.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Fencing Championships (5–7–3 1958 Philadelphia bronze: foil; 1959 Budapest gold: foil team; 1961 Torino silver: foil team; 1962 Buenos Aires gold: foil team; 1963 Gdańsk gold: foil, silver: foil team; 1966 Moskva silver: foil team; 1967 Montréal gold: foil team; 1969 La Habana bronze: foil team; 1971 Wien silver: foil and foil team; 1973 Göteborg gold: foil team, bronze: foil; 1974 Grenoble silver: foil team; 1975 Budapest silver: foil team) Listed in Olympians With a Disability (Profoundly deaf.)

name: Howard Winfree
description: Howard Winfree attended the US Naval Academy at Annapolis, graduating in 1961. In 1960 the Naval Academy eight won the title at the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen (NAAO) meet, which doubled as the Olympic Trials. The Midshipmen eight placed fifth at the 1960 Olympics, breaking the US streak of winning the rowing eights, which extended from 1920-56.

name: Verner Weckman
description: Inspired by circus wrestlers, Verner Weckman, a farmer’s boy from Loviisa, started Greco-Roman wrestling in 1902 and won his only Finnish title in 1904 in the heavyweight class. In 1905 Weckman started study at the University of Karlsruhe (now the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology), and, while in Germany, won the unofficial 1905 World Championship in Duisburg in the heavyweight class against five Germans. In 1906, Finland took part in the Olympic Games for the first time and Weckman became the first Finn to win Olympic gold when he won the Greco-Roman middleweight class. This also allowed him to compete in the all-around competition, where the winners of all the weight classes competed for the all-around title, but Weckman lost his match against heavyweight winner Søren Jensen and had to settle for a silver medal. Two years later, Weckman competed again at the Olympic arena and won a gold medal in the Greco-Roman light-heavyweight event. Weckman retired from sports after the 1908 Olympics and after graduating from the University of Karlsruhe with an engineering degree, worked as an engineer in Russia from 1909-21. In 1921, Weckman returned to Finland and worked at Suomen Kaapelitehdas Oy (Finnish Cable Works), which in 1967 was merged with two other companies to form Nokia Corporation, where he served as the longtime executive director until 1955.

name: Wang Zhiming
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (3–1–0 1986 Seoul FEN gold: sabre team, silver: sabre; 1990 Beijing FEN gold: sabre and sabre team)

name: Emily Freeman
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Athletics Championships (0–1–0 2006 Göteborg silver: 4×100 m relay) Listed in Olympians Who Were on the Podium at Ironman races (0–0–1 2019 Ironman United Kingdom; Bolton, GBR third)

name: Ian Bowditch
description: Ian Bowditch fenced team épée for Australia at the 1964 Tokyo Olympics. He competed in fencing while a student at Melbourne University, where he studied law. He and his brother, Bruce, both were awarded Full Blues as fencers. After serving in the Australian Air Force, Ian Bowditch worked for the Crown Solicitors Office in Brisbane, and continued to compete in fencing at Brisbane University. After the Tokyo Olympics he was a junior at a Country Legal Practice in Rochester, but soon left to work for the Australian government in Nauru, where he was a legal officer and helped draft the constitution for the country before their independence. He was married in Nauru but he and his wife returned to Australia in 1970, where he started a small legal practice in Elsternwick. He also lectured at the Footscray Institute of Technology. He joined the bar in November 1983, and stayed at the bar until 2003, when illness forced him to stop practicing.

name: Gertrude Bohnert
description: Gertrude Bohnert married her colleague, the painter Hans Erni in 1946. Their daughter Simone Erni (*1946) also became a famous Swiss painter and graphic artist. In the late 1920s, Bohnert studied at the School of Arts and Crafts in Luzern and the Academy Julian in Paris. She also made several study trips throughout Europe. She started as a porcelain painter, but was best known as a glass and crystal engraver. Her objects were mainly decorative animal and plant patterns. Later, she also produced glass sculptures. Bohnert was killed in 1948 in a riding accident.
special_notes: Wife of Hans Erni

name: Glenn Kable
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Shooting Championships (1–0–0 1999 Tampere gold: trap team (competed for Australia))

name: Zhao Chengliang
description: Personal Best: 50kmW – 3-36:13 (2005).

name: Heinz Laufer
description: Heinz Laufer came in an unfortunate fourth in the steeplechase at the 1956 Melbourne Olympics. The long-distance runner won six West German Championships and an additional two indoor titles. In 1959 he was awarded the Silver Bay Leaf. Laufer was a member of the German Communistic Party (DKP), and served on the council in his hometown of Stuttgart from 1968-75. In 1967 he was a founding member of the Democratic Left Party (DL) and one year later of the DKP. His special interests were social issues, housing and transport planning. After his active career Laufer became a critic of the German Athletics Federation DLV and was therefore often used as a figurehead by the GDR propaganda machine. His son Eberhard also became a long-distance runner. Personal Best: 3000S – 8:44.53 (1956).

name: Thomas Webster
description: Tom Webster was a member of the California Yacht Club. He sailed as a crew member with Pierpont Davis aboard the Santa Maria in the Olympic Trials in Los Angeles Harbor. Davis finished second to Owen Churchill, but Churchill invited all of Davis’s crew members to work as crew in at least some of the Olympic races, allowing all of them to receive gold medals, including Webster.

name: Filip Zubčić
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Alpine Ski Championships (0–1–0 2021 Cortina d'Ampezzo silver: parallel)

name: Lidiya Hunko
special_notes: Listed in Doping Irregularities at the Olympics (2022 Beijing – Monobob (20); Disqualified in March 2023 after investigation and found to have a positive ADRV for Turinabol metabolites.)

name: Liu Yunchang
description: Liu Yunzhang, later known as Liu Zhuofu, participated in the 1936 Berlin Olympics with the basketball team of the Republic of China and graduated from the biology department of the Beijing Normal University in the same year. In 1938, Liu joined the Communist Party. During the war, he was a member of the so-called “Combat Basketball team”, which was founded in the region controlled by the 120th division. After the founding of the People’s Republic of China, he served as the deputy minister in the Ministry of Commerce, responsible for the Agricultural Products Purchasing and Urban Service Departments, as deputy governor of the Yunnan Provincial People’s Committee, the secretary of the Yunnan Provincial Committee of the Communist Party of China, director of the State General Administration of Prices and as delegate at the fifth and sixth National People’s Congress.

name: Gösta Svensson
description: Gösta Svensson was a high jumper who placed fourth at the 1952 Helsinki Olympics and fifth at the 1950 European Championships. He set a Swedish record with 2.02 in 1952, his personal best. Svensson never won a Swedish title but placed second in 1953 and 1956. Personal Best: HJ – 2.02 (1952).

name: Lucie Décosse
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (1–1–0 2001 Tunis JUD silver: half-middleweight -63 kg; 2005 Almería JUD gold: half-middleweight -63 kg) Listed in Olympians Who Were Awarded the Prix Monique Berlioux (2012)

name: Eric Wilson
description: Eric Wilson placed fourth at the 1924 Olympic Trials 400 to make the Olympic Team. A graduate of the University of Iowa, he won Big Ten title for that school in 1921 and 1923. He then spent 44 years at the university as its sports information director (SID). Personal Best: 400 – 47.7 (1924).

name: Minoru Sano
description: Minoru Sano had the following placements at major international championships - Men: 1973 World Championships (14th); 1974 World Championships (8th); 1975 World Championships (10th); 1976 World Championships (7th); 1977 World Championships (3rd).

name: Luciano Caravani
description: Luciano Caravani was a sprinter who represented Fiamme Oro Padova (the police athletics club) and his personal best 100 metres was 10.23, done in September 1979 in Mexico City, while his best 200 metres was 20.59, set in Algiers in July 1979. He competed at the 1976 Olympics where he was sixth in the 4x100 relay (first leg) and was eliminated in the 100 m quarter-finals. At the Mediterranean Games he won a silver medal in the 1975 4x100 relay behind France, while in 1979 at Split he won the 200 metres in 20.74, and helped Italy win the 4x100 relay. Between 1975-83 Caravani earned 34 international caps. In the Italian championships he won gold in 1977 in the 100 and in 1975 in the indoor 60 metres. Personal Best: 100 – 10.23 (1979).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (1–1–0 1977 Sofia ATH silver: 4×100 m relay; 1979 Ciudad de México ATH gold: 4×100 m relay) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (2–1–0 1975 Al-Jaza'ir ATH silver: 4×100 m relay; 1979 Split ATH gold: 200 m and 4×100 m relay)

name: Alessandro Pirzio Biroli
description: Alessandro Pirzio Biroli was an Italian Army General and fencer. At the 1908 London Olympics he won a silver medal in the team sabre behind Hungary. After World War I he became the commanding officer for the Bersaglieri Regiment and between 1921-27 headed a military mission to Ecuador. He was also commander of the Monte Nero Division and led the Italian 5th Trieste Corps. From 1936-37 he was Chief of Staff in the Eritrean Corps in the Second Italo-Abyssinian war. With Fascist sympathies, Pirzio Biroli was made General of the Italian 9th Army in 1941 and was Governor of Montenegro from 1941-43, holding complete civil and military powers. Pirzio Biroli was personally responsible for numerous executions and the mass terror of Montenegro’s population. Despite being considered a war criminal by the United Nations, he was never tried and spent his last years in Roma where he died in 1962 at 84-years-old.

name: Giovanni Stradone
description: Painter Giovanni Stradone earned the silver medal at the 1948 Art Competitions in London for his work Il ciclista in pista (Cyclist on the Track) in the category Paintings. He was a noted typical Italian expressionist, but sent in several rather neo-cubist works depicting track cycling, and Fausto Coppi in particular. Stradone was an avid cyclist himself. Later his style showed an increasing degree of abstraction, eventually only reflecting moods and feelings. As a youngster living in Rome, he often went to the Borghese Museum, copying the works of old masters like Raphael. After graduating from high school, he studied law following his parents’ wishes but never worked in this field. At the same time he also developed a keen interest in entomology. Initially, he belonged to the so-called “Roman School” before he had his breakthrough in the 1940s as an expressionist. In 1950 he created a scandal by exhibiting his painting “L’apoteosi di Bartali”, another famous Italian cyclist, at the Biennale in Venezia. Later, he was rediscovered as a member of the “Roman School”. His last major exhibitions were held in between 1978 and 1981, shortly before his sudden death. The successful oil painting is shown in the catalog of art competitions. Therefore, there is no doubt about its identity, although on the official website of the artist, his family states that the 1948 neo-cubist work Coppi in Pista was the one awarded silver in the art competitions. Another entry was the pen and wash drawing Cyclist, which is also represented in the catalog. A line drawing with the same title could not be identified.

name: René Besserve
description: René Besserve was a French painter, illustrator and cartoonist, who sometimes used the pseudonym Henry Reb. He was educated at the École des Beaux-Arts Montpellier and the Académie Julian Paris. From 1911-40 he produced drawings for Cri de Paris and Rire, in 1912 for Ruy Blas, and in 1915 for Fantasio. Besserve produced frequent humorous political illustrations in a cubistic style. Besserve, who worked in Paris, also created several posters such as for the 1928 Chamonix Winter Olympics. As a painter Besserve mostly painted landscapes of the Paris region and Brittany, but also portraits in oil and watercolor. He primarily exhibited in Paris, notably from 1920-38 at the Salon d’Automne, 1926-38 at the Salon des Indépendants, and 1928-39 at the Salon des Tuileries.

name: Kurt Einsiedel
description: Kurt Einsiedel was a member of the German team pursuit cycling team at the 1928 Amsterdam Games. The team was eliminated in the quarter-finals by the eventual champions Italy. He also competed in the 1,000 metres time-trial and finished fifth. Einsiedel competed for RRC Excelsior Dresden.

name: Solomon Bockarie-Bayoh
description: Adopted Dutch nationality on 21 May 2015. Personal Bests: 100 – 10.13 (2016); 200 – 20.37 (2016).

name: Vladimir Ukhov
description: Personal Best: 50kmW – 4-11:23 (1956).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Athletics Championships (1–0–0 1954 Bern gold: 50 km walk)

name: Christian Reich
description: Christian Reich took up bobsledding in 1986 and, by 1989, was good enough to win silver in the four-man at the World Championships alongside Donat Acklin and the non-Olympians Nico Baracchi and René Mangold. He first attended the Winter Olympics in 1992, where he was 10th in the two-man with Christian Meili, fifth in the four-man alongside Meili, Bruno Gerber, and Gerold Löffler, and he was seventh in the four-man at the 1994 edition with Löffler, Meili, and René Schmidheiny. In 1995 Reich switched to piloting and, by 1997, was competing at the World Championships once again, where he won a silver medal in the four-man. He was disqualified, however, alongside the first- and third-placing Swiss teams, for competing with a bobsled that the national team had been using all season, unaware that it was illegal. At the 1998 Winter Olympics he was fourth in the two-man with Cédric Grand and seventh in the four-man alongside Grand, Steve Anderhub, and Thomas Handschin, before taking silver in the two-man with Urs Aeberhard at the 1999 European Championships. Reich’s career really took off in 2000, when he was overall World Cup champion in the two-man and runner-up in the combined. He and Aeberhard also captured bronze in the two- and four-man events at the World Championships, with the assistance of non-Olympians Bruno Aeberhard and Domenic Keller in the latter. In 2001 Reich and Anderhub were runners-up in the two-man at the European Championships and, in 2002, won that title. Reich was also runner-up in the combined and third in the two- and four-man in the World Cup standings that season, but his greatest success came at that year’s Winter Olympics, where he and Anderhub won silver in the two-man. They also came in sixth in the four-man alongside Urs Aeberhard and Guido Acklin. Reich retired from active competition shortly thereafter and worked as head coach of the Monégasque national team until 2006. He was also involved in bobsledding at a technical level, running a business that manufactured sleds (including those used by the Swiss team the 2010 Games), and became Vice President of Corporate and Financial Affairs of the International Bobsleigh & Skeleton Federation in 2010.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Bob & Skeleton Championships (1–2–0 1999 Winterberg silver: Two-man; 2001 Königssee silver: Two-man; 2002 Cortina d’Ampezzo gold: Two-man) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Bob & Skeleton Championships (FIBT/IBSF) (0–1–3 1989 Cortina d'Ampezzo silver: Four-man; 2000 Altenberg bronze: Two-man and Four-man; 2001 St. Moritz bronze: Four-man)

name: Pam Bileck
description: Pam Bileck was only a sophomore in high school when she made the 1984 US Olympic team. She later attended UCLA, graduating magna cum laude in communications and business. Bileck was US Champion on beam in 1984 and competed for the US at the 1983 and 1985 World Championships. She later became an official, achieving a brevet level judge’s certification, and officiating at national and international meets. She also coached at the Elite and TOPS Training Camps. Bileck eventually worked in entertainment with the Zanuck Company and Disney Studios.

name: Jennifer Gillom
description: Jennifer Gillom won a basketball gold medal with the US team at the 1987 Pan American Games and at the 1988 Seoul Olympics. Gillom played in college at the University of Mississippi. She played in the WNBA with the Phoenix Mercury from 1997-2002, and then played one final year with the Los Angeles Sparks. She was All-WNBA in 1998 and in the 2002/03 season, Gillom won the Kim Perrot Sportsmanship Award. Gillom later became a coach, starting in 2006 as a high school coach in Phoenix, Arizona. In 2008 she became an assistant with the Minnesota Lynx, and in 2009 she moved up to head coach of the team. She later was an assistant with the Connecticut Sun. Gillom was an assistant coach for the US National team at the 2010 World Championships and the 2012 Olympics, both times helping them win gold medals. In 2009 she was elected to the Women’s Basketball Hall of Fame.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 1987 Indianapolis BAS gold) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–1–0 1985 Kobe BAS silver) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Basketball World Cup (2–0–0 1986 URS gold; 2002 CHN gold)

name: Aarne Honkavaara
description: Aarne Honkavaara was considered the best Finnish hockey player of the 1940s and early 1950s. He played his entire Finnish career with Ilves Tampere, starting in 1943, playing through the 1951-52 season. He was then out a year with a broken leg sustained in a game against Poland, and then coached for three years, before returning to Ilves to play from 1956-58. He also briefly played a couple exhibition games in Canada with Sarnia Sailors. Honkavaara earned 47 caps for Finland, playing at the 1952 Winter Olympics and the 1949 and 1951 World Championships. The Arne Honkavaara Trophy is awarded to the leading regular season goalscorer in the Finnish SM-Liiga. Honkavaara is a member of the International Ice Hockey Hall of Fame and the Finnish Hockey Hall of Fame.

name: Wang Xinyan
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (1–0–0 2014 Incheon WPO gold)

name: Herbert Kastinger
description: Austrian architect Herbert Kastinger studied in Wien (Vienna). He died young from a cerebral hemorrhage, but in his short career worked exclusively with his colleague Hermann Stiegholzer. Together they built the first Labour Office in Wien after the Dessau model of Walter Gropius, but Kastinger also worked in industrial and residential construction. Their construction of the Vienna Race Courses for cars, cycling and equestrian sports in the Viennese district of Simmering won the bronze medal at the 1936 Berlin Olympic Games in the category Architectural Designs. The project was not realized.

name: Karsten Huck
description: Karsten Huck was a West German equestrian who surprisingly won an individual bronze medal at the 1988 Seoul show jumping event. In 1990, Huck won a team silver at the World Equestrian Games. By profession, he was a managing director of a Hamburg apartment management company until 1977. He then became a professional equestrian coach with his own stable. From 1978-86 Huck was Chief Regional Coach at Schleswig-Holstein.

name: Muriel Noah Ahanda
description: Personal Best: 400 – 53.74 (2002).

name: Seth Kelsey
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (3–0–1 2003 Santo Domingo FEN gold: sabre team; 2007 Rio de Janeiro FEN bronze: épée team; 2011 Guadalajara FEN gold: épée and épée team) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Fencing Championships (1–1–0 2010 Paris silver: épée team; 2012 Kyiv gold: épée team)

name: Carlos Arena
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games (0–2–1 1998 Maracaibo SWI silver: 200 m backstroke and 4×100 m medley relay, bronze: 4×100 m freestyle relay)

name: José Antonio Escuredo
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (0–1–1 1991 Athina CYC silver: sprint, bronze: 1000 m time trail)

name: Fred Rodriguez
description: Fred Rodriguez was a road cyclist who competed in the road race at the 2000 Sydney Olympics. He raced professionally from 1996-2015 with various teams. Rodriguez was known as a sprint specialist, leading to the nickname “Fast Freddy”. Rodriguez was US National Champion four times in the road race, in 2000-01, 2004, and 2013. He won four stages at the Tour of Georgia and stage nine of the 2004 Giro d’Italia. That was the only year he rode the Giro and he also rode the Vuelta a España one time, in 2006, and he finished both those grand tours. Rodriguez rode the Tour de France seven times but finished it only in 2000 and 2005. In major one-day international races Rodriguez finished second at both Milano-San Remo and Gent-Wevelgem in 2002. As a sprinter he won the green jersey at the 2000 Tour de Suisse and the 2003 and 2006 Tour of Georgia, and he was second on GC at the 2003 Tour of Georgia. His other victories included the 1996 International Cycling Classic, the 2000 First Union Classic, the 2001 US Pro Championship, and in 2004, the Wachovia Classic and the Reading Classic.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–0–1 1995 Mar del Plata CYC bronze: road race)

name: Geoffrey Picard
description: Geoffrey Picard was only selected as an alternate to the 1964 rowing team but he was moved into the four shell when Phil Durbrow became ill and collapsed after the first heat. Picard, rowing with a completely new crew and in a completely different style, adapted well enough to help the four win a bronze medal. Picard was a student at Harvard in 1964 and eventually earned an M.B.A. from that school. While there he rowed all four years, helping the Crimson win the Eastern Sprints in 1964 and 1965 and beating Yale every year. After earning his M.B.A. he joined the investment banking world with the firm of Morgan Stanley & Co., where he later became a partner and vice-president. Picard specialized in building Asian markets, and was a co-founder and managing director of Asia Pacific Securities. He was a member of the board of advisers to the chairman of the Securities and Futures Commission, and in that role helped draft the securities law for the People’s Republic of China.

name: Joy Fawcett
description: Joy Fawcett was a defender who played football (soccer) for the US at three Olympics, winning golds in 1996 and 2004, and a silver medal in 2000. Fawcett also played at four FIFA World Cups, helping the USA win the title in 1991 and 1999, and winning bronze medals in 1995 and 2003. Fawcett earned 241 caps during her international career and was on the US National Team from 1987-2004. Fawcett played soccer in college at U Cal Berkeley, where she made All-American three times and set the school single-season scoring record in 1987 with 23 goals. Fawcett played professionally in Europe with Ajax and later played for the San Diego Spirit. She became a soccer coach, coaching UCLA from 1993-97. Fawcett was inducted into the US Soccer Hall of Fame in 2009.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Participated in the 2004 Olympic Football Qualification Campaign (women) (4 App. - 0 goals - 315 min. played: CONCACAF Olympic Qualifying Tournament in Costa Rica: TRI 7:0, HAI 8:0 (bench), MEX 2:0, CRC 4:0, MEX 3:2) Listed in Olympic Footballers - Gold Medalists and World Cup Champions, Women (Olympic Gold - 1996/2004; World Cup Champion - 1991/1999.) Listed in Olympians Who Were Named Sports Illustrated's Sportsman of the Year (1999 USA Women's World Cup Soccer Team, 1999 Sports Illustrated Sportsman of the Year)

name: Piotr Buciarski
description: Personal Best: PV – 5.75 (2002).
special_notes: Son of Wojciech Buciarski Husband of Rachel Yurkovich

name: Lidia Talpă
description: Lidia Talpă had the following podium finishes at the Flatwater World Championships: 2nd 2005 K4 1000 m (with Florica Vulpeș and the non-Olympians Mariana Ciobanu and Alina Platon), 3rd 2006 K4 500 m (with Florica Vulpeș and the non-Olympians Mariana Ciobanu and Alina Platon).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Canoe Sprint European Championships (1–0–5 2004 Poznań gold: K4 1000 m; 2005 Poznań bronze: K4 1000 m; 2006 Račice bronze: K4 500 m and K4 1000 m; 2008 Milano bronze: K2 1000 m and K4 1000 m) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Canoe Sprint World Championships (0–1–1 2005 Zagreb silver: K4 1000 m; 2006 Szeged bronze: K4 500 m)

name: Cliff Meidl
description: Cliff Meidl competed as a flatwater kayaker at the 1996 and 2000 Olympics. He was lucky to be there. In 1986 Meidl was working construction at age 20 when he sustained severe electrical burns that almost caused him to lose both his legs. He had been operating a jackhammer when he made contact with live electrical cables. He went into cardiac arrest and sustained burns and exit wounds over 15% of his body with severe damage to both knees. Not expected to walk again, he persevered and competed at two Olympic Games. In 2000 Meidl was chosen as the US Flagbearer at the Opening Ceremony for his inspirational story. Meidl started college at El Camino College, before finishing at Cal State Long Beach. He later earned an MBA from the University of Southern California. After his sports career he became an asset management consultant and a successful motivational speaker. After the publicity he received at the 2000 Sydney Olympics, he received a number of awards, including the Arete Courage in Sports Award, the Philadelphia Sportswriters’ Courage Award, and the Los Angeles Marathon Patsy Choco Award. He was also named as one of the 20 all-time inspirational Olympians for the Olympian Heroes Series.

name: Noriko Yamaji
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (1–2–0 1994 Hiroshima SOF silver; 1998 Bangkok SOF silver; 2002 Busan SOF gold)

name: Allie Morrison
description: At the University of Illinois, Allie Morrison never lost a dual match in three years. He claimed three AAU Championships, winning that title at 135 lbs. from 1926-1928. In high school, Morrison had won Iowa state championships as a sophomore and junior, but was ineligible his senior year because he was too old. However, his coach was future basketball coaching legend Adolph Rupp, who knew nothing about wrestling, so he basically let Morrison coach the team his senior year. Morrison also played college football at Illinois, teaming with one of the all-time greats of the sport, Red Grange. After the 1928 Olympics, Morrison returned to Illinois for his senior year, but broke a vertebrae in his neck and was forced to give up the sport. After his wrestling career ended, he became a wrestling and football coach. Morrison started coaching at Penn State, and then became football and wrestling coach at Doane College, outside of Omaha, Nebraska. He later left college coaching to teach English and coach at Omaha Central High School. Morrison was made a member of the Iowa High School Wrestling Hall of Fame in 1977, the Nebraska Scholastic Wrestling Coaches Association in 1982, the University of Nebraska-Omaha Athletics Hall of Fame inaugural class in 1996, the Des Moines Register Sports Hall of Fame in 2008, and was named a Distinguished Member of the National Wrestling Hall of Fame in 1993.

name: August Ehrich
description: German gymnast August Ehrich competed at the 1908 London Olympics. He finished 65th in the individual all-around event. He was a member of Turnerschaft Charlottenburg.

name: Marco Zanchi
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Participated in the 2000 Olympic Football Qualification Campaign (men) (13 App. - 0 goals - 1200 min. played: WAL 2:1 (a), SUI 1:0 (h), DEN 2:1 (a), BLR 4:1 (h), WAL 6:2 (h), SUI 0:0 (a), BLR 2:1 (a), FRA 1:1 (a), FRA 2:1 a.e.t. (h); European Under-21 Championship in the Slovakia: ENG 2:0, SVK 1:1, TUR 3:1, CZE 2:1)

name: Tobias Arwidson
special_notes: Son of Lars-Göran Arwidson Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Biathlon Championships (0–1–0 2013 Bansko silver: 20 km)

name: Zdzisław Krzyszkowiak
description: Zdzisław Krzyszkowiak won 13 Polish titles in long-distance and cross-country events. Krzyszkowiak came to international attention at the 1956 Olympics, where he missed the bronze medal by 7.4 seconds, finishing fourth. At the 1958 European Championships, Krzyszkowiak established himself as one the best European long distance runners, winning both the 5,000 and 10,000 metres. Just two months before the Roma Olympics, Krzyszkowiak ran his first world record, clocking 8.31.4 in the steeplechase. At the Olympics itself, Krzyszkowiak finished seventh in the 10K, but as expected, won the steeplechase. After Roma, Krzyszkowiak concentrated on the 3,000 m steeplechase, setting his second world record in 1961, but was forced to retire from sports prematurely in 1963 due to injuries. After his running career, Krzyszkowiak worked as an athletics coach. Personal Bests: 10000 – 28:52.75 (1960); 3000S – 8:30.4 (1961).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Athletics Championships (2–0–0 1958 Stockholm gold: 5000 m and 10000 m) Listed in Olympic Order Recipients (1987 (Silver))

name: Charles H. Foster
description: Although born in Canada, Charles Foster emigrated to the United States in 1915 and became a US citizen in 1918. He was a walker whose best finishes in AAU competition came from 1922-25 in the 5 km. walk, when he placed in the top four every year, finishing second in 1923. He competed for the Detroit TC and Detroit YMCA. Foster worked as an auto mechanic. Personal Best: 10 kmW – 49:09 (1924).

name: Paulo Martins
description: Paulo Martins had the following finishes at major championships – 1991 World Championship: 74.0 kg. Greco-Roman (21st); 1991 European Championship: 74.0 kg. Greco-Roman (10th); 1992 European Championship: 74.0 kg. Freestyle (19th).

name: Fausto Acke
description: Fausto Padovini was born in Roma but was orphaned at age six in 1903, and was then adopted by Johan Axel Gustav Acke and his wife Eva, Swedish impressionist painters and friends of his parents, who had died during an epidemic. His mother by adoption was the daughter of Zacharias Topelius (1818-98), a well-known Finnish writer in the Swedish language. Fausto Acke grew up in the city of Vaxholm and competed at the Olympic Games in Antwerpen in the Team All-Around, Swedish System, in which he won a gold medal. In 1925 Acke married Gerdis Sung, a sculptor and designer. In the same year he moved to Hollywood, California in the United States, where he worked in the film industry. Acke also competed in athletics as a discus thrower, with a personal best of 41.97 set in Stockholm on 13 June 1920.

name: Gabi Nance
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–1–0 2018 Gold Coast HOK silver)

name: Grant Nel
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–1–2 2010 Delhi DIV bronze: 3 m springboard; 2014 Glasgow DIV silver: synchronized springboard, bronze: 1 m springboard)

name: Tom Dolan
description: Tom Dolan was an individual medley specialist who was the world’s greatest all-around swimmer in the later half of the 1990s. He won gold medals in the 400 IM at the 1996 and 2000 Olympics, adding a silver medal in the 200 IM at Sydney. Dolan won the 400 IM at both the 1994 and 1998 World Championships and won both individual medleys at the 1995 Pan Pacific Championships, after winning silver in the 400 IM at the 1993 Pan Pacs. Dolan set two world records in the 400 IM, at the 1994 Worlds and the 2000 Olympics. Dolan swam in college at the University of Michigan. He won six individual NCAA titles, winning the 500 yd freestyle, the 1,650 yd freestyle, and the 400 yard IM, all in 1995-96. He also helped Michigan win the 4x200 yd freestyle relay in 1994-96. Dolan was inducted into the International Swimming Hall of Fame in 2006 and the Virginia Sports Hall of Fame in 2009. He later ran the Tom Dolan Swim School in Northern Virginia, helping teach all ages of swimmers.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Set a World Record in Long Course Swimming (400 m medley – 11 September 1994 - 15 August 2002: 4:12.30 (11 September 1994; Roma, ITA), 4:11.76 (17 September 2000; Sydney, AUS)) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Pan Pacific Swimming Championships (2–3–0 1993 Kobe silver: 400 m medley; 1995 Atlanta gold: 200 m medley and 400 m medley, silver: 200 m backstroke and 4×200 m freestyle relay) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Aquatics Championships (2–0–0 1994 Roma SWI gold: 400 m medley; 1998 Perth SWI gold: 400 m medley)

name: Ewa Swoboda
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Athletics Indoor Championships (1–0–1 2017 Beograd bronze: 60 m; 2019 Glasgow gold: 60 m)

name: Eli Pasquale
description: Eli Pasquale took up basketball in high school, but did not begin to shine until he entered the University of Victoria. There, he helped the school capture five consecutive Canadian collegiate titles from 1980 through 1984 and earned a degree in economics. During that time, he débuted internationally with the Canadian team at the 1982 World Championships, where the country placed sixth. A year later, he helped Canada win gold at the Universiade and followed it up with bronze in that tournament in 1985. In-between he attended the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics, where Canada lost the bronze medal match to Yugoslavia. He was drafted by the Seattle SuperSonics that year, but he was released after three exhibition games. He did eventually play professionally in Argentina, West Germany, and Spain, but although he tried out with the Chicago Bulls in 1985, he never joined the NBA officially. Pasquale made a second Olympic appearance for Canada at the 1988 Seoul Games, where the nation placed sixth overall. He retired from active competition in 1992, although he had a brief comeback in 1997 before retiring for good. By career, he ran his own company, the Eli Pasquale Group, which ran youth basketball camps. He was made a member of the Canadian Basketball Hall of Fame in 2003 and the British Columbia Sports Hall of Fame in 2004.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (1–0–0 1983 Edmonton BAS gold)

name: Muhammad Halim
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games (0–2–0 2010 Mayagüez ATH silver: long jump; 2014 Veracruz ATH silver: long jump)

name: Margo Walters
description: Margo Walters began skiing in Bear Gulch, Idaho in 1951, made the US Junior ski team in 1957, and won the Intermountain Junior Championships from 1958-60. She first skied in Europe in 1962, and was at her best there in the downhill. In 1963 she was on the podium at most of the major US races, including a victory at the Snow Cup giant slalom, second in the Roche Cup downhill and slalom, and third at the Harriman Cup downhill. Walters later served as Executive Director of the Intermountain Ski Association from 1967-70.

name: Tobias Barnerssoi
description: Tobias Barnerssoi was one of the best German Alpine skiers in giant slalom and super G, but never won an international medal. At the 1994 Lillehammer Winter Olympics he finished 14th in the combined event as his best result. He participated in several World Championships but without success. Nationally, Barnerssoi won four titles in giant slalom (1991, 1993-95) and two in super G (1997-98). He later became a sports reporter, commenting with the German TV channel ARD, mostly on Alpine ski events and Olympic Games.

name: Harold James
description: Harold James was educated at Clifton College, Bristol where he shot for the rifle shooting team and was a member of the VIII that won the prestigious Ashburton Shield at Wimbledon in 1884. During World War I, James assisted with rifle shooting training of the Southern Command of Kitchener’s Army. He was also a good standard archer, and both James and his wife Annie were members of the Backwell and District Archery Club. At the 1908 Olympics, despite being one of only two contestants not to hit a gold, James managed to finish in sixth place. An all-round sportsman, James was a good golfer, was captain of the Flax Bourton Cricket Club for many years and was also Master of the North Somerset Hounds. He was a Bristol grain merchant and broker by profession.

name: Dani Samuels-Stevens
description: Personal Best: DT – 67.99 (2014).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (1–1–0 2007 Bangkok ATH silver: discus throw; 2009 Beograd ATH gold: discus throw) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Athletics Championships (1–1–0 2009 Berlin gold: discus throw; 2017 London silver: discus throw (competed as Dani Stevens)) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (2–0–1 2006 Melbourne ATH bronze: discus throw; 2014 Glasgow ATH gold: discus throw; 2018 Gold Coast ATH gold: discus throw (competed as Dani Stevens))

name: Ai Kondo-Yoshida
special_notes: Wife of Yugo Yoshida

name: Nikolay Chernetsky
description: Nikolay Chernetsky ran the third leg for the Soviet 4×400 metre team that won gold at the 1980 Olympics. He was also on the Soviet 4x400 relay that won gold at the 1983 World Championships. Besides those two titles, Chernetsky won 400 gold at the 1980 European Indoors and bronze at that meet in 1978, adding 400 silvers at the 1979 World Cup and European Cups. Chernetsky won three Soviet titles – 400 in 1979-80; and 4×400 relay in 1979. After his retirement from sports, Chernetsky worked as an athletics coach and he emigrated to Italy after the fall of the Soviet Union. In the 1980s, Chernetsky was married to Iolanda Chen, who was the world’s leading female triple jumper in the early 1990s, held the women’s triple jump world record in 1993, and won silver at the 1993 World Championships. Chernetsky’s sister Tatyana Chernetskaya was the leading female modern pentathlete of the world in the 1980s, winning multiple World and European titles. Personal Best: 400 – 45.12 (1979).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Athletics Indoor Championships (1–0–1 1978 Milano bronze: 400 m; 1980 Sindelfingen gold: 400 m) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Athletics Championships (1–0–0 1983 Helsinki gold: 4×400 m relay)

name: Barbara Schwarzfeldt
description: West German Barbara Schwarzfeldt competed in the 800 m freestyle at the 1972 München Olympics, but was eliminated in the heats. However, in 1974, she won a bronze medal at the European Championships in Vienna in the 200 m butterfly. She was subsequently awarded the Silver Bay Leaf, Germany’s highest sports award. Schwarzfeldt won five national titles: 200 m freestyle in 1974, 400 m freestyle 1976, 200 m butterfly 1974-75, and 400 m individual medley in 1976.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Aquatics Championships (0–1–1 1974 Wien SWM silver: 4×100 m medley relay (swam in heats only), bronze: 200 m butterfly)

name: Clara Schroth-Lomady
description: Clara Schroth-Lomady has dominated United States women’s gymnastics like no one else. She won 39 national titles between 1941 and 1952, including an amazing 11 straight (1941-1951) on the balance beam. She won six all-around titles, won championships on all four standard apparatuses, and won five U.S. championships on the flying rings, an event no longer contested by women. For variety she also won a silver medal in the long jump at the 1945 AAU Women’s Track & Field Championships. Clara Schroth worked during her competitive years as a secretary with the Abington School District, trained at night, and won her Olympic medal under that name. In 1951 she married Wendell “Fuzz” Lomady and was a devoted mother and wife. She has also been active with the U.S. Gymnastics Federation. She was inducted into the USA Gymnastics Hall of Fame in 1974.

name: Stefan Zünd
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Were on the Podium at the Four Hills Tournament (1991/92 Oberstdorf third, Garmisch-Partenkirchen third)

name: Sylvester Wackerle, Jr.
description: Ice hockey defenseman Sylvester Wackerle, Jr. competed at the 1964 Innsbruck Winter Olympics tournament, with the German team finishing seventh. He earned 25 international caps with the West German national team, also playing at the 1963 World Championships. Domestically Wackerle played exclusively for SC Riessersee, winning the West German Championships in 1960. In 1994 he took over the “Gasthaus Bräustüberl” in Garmisch. Both, his father Sylvester Wackerle, Sr. and his brother Anton Wackerle were Olympic bobsleigh athletes.
special_notes: Son of Sylvester Wackerle, Sr. Brother of Anton Wackerle

name: Eberhard Radzik
description: West German boxer Eberhard Radzik was born in Gelsenkirchen, but later moved to Stuttgart. He lost his first round bout at the 1960 Roma Olympic Games in the middleweight class against Moussa El-Gelidi from the United Arab Republic (Egypt). Nothing else is known about Radzik’s life.

name: Wolfgang Schmelzer
description: Cyclist Wolfgang Schmelzer was a member of the East German track pursuit team eliminated in the qualifying round at the 1968 Mexico Olympics. In 1961, 1963, and 1965-67, he was East German Madison champion with Siegfried Köhler. In 1961-64, 1966 and 1969 he also won team pursuit titles with Einheit TSC Berlin. Schmelzer added further motor-pacing titles. He later became a professional photographer.

name: Anton Hangel
description: Anton Hangel was an Austrian weightlifter who finished seventh at the 1928 Amsterdam Olympics in the lightweight class. He then moved up to middleweight and placed an unfortunate fourth at the 1936 Berlin Games. In 1934, he won his only Austrian national title, and was a silver medallist in 1933 and 1938, and third in 1935. He also won the Wien (Vienna) Championship in 1936 and 1938-39.

name: Audun Boysen
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Athletics Championships (0–1–1 1954 Bern bronze: 800 m; 1958 Stockholm silver: 800 m)

name: Detlef Ultsch
description: East German middleweight judoka Detlef Ultsch participated at the 1976 Montréal Olympics with limited success, but won a bronze medal four years later at Moskva. In 1979, Ultsch became the first German World Champion in judo. He repeated this triumph in 1983 and won a bronze in 1981. He also won a silver at the 1978 Europeans and bronze medals in 1976-77, 1979-80, and 1982-83. Domestically, he won six national titles. Ultsch then turned to coaching. Since 1980 he was a member of the national coaching team in East Germany, and after re-unification, he was chief youth coach in Germany. In 2009 he became chief national coach until 2016, while in 2017 he became chief coach of the federal police. His son Christian also became a judoka.

name: Nora Rocha

special_notes: Husband of Jean Stewart Father of Gary Hurring Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–2–0 1954 Vancouver SWI silver: 110 yards backstroke and 3×110 yards medley)
